body:
I came here to be pedantic and bug you about "saving a few nanos" but then I did the hand wavey math.

Assuming the GPR_ASSERT is the "rightly" predicted branch, which it surely will be, then [this pic](http://ithare.com/wp-content/uploads/part101_infographics_v08.png) says upper bound of 20 cycles.

`lscpu | grep MHz` on my desktop shows ~1500MHz (though it's max is double this).

So 20 cycles / (1.5e9 cycles per sec) = 1.33e-8 sec = 13 nanoseconds.

Nice

Oh wait, I misread that chart. It's ~2 cycles, not 20. That makes more sense... So ~1.3 nanos. You still win.

That being said, I will believe that asserts and untaken tracing paths affect macro performance when I see the data.

~~Hahaha this would still save 20 cycles when a closure is scheduled/run. It was assert earlier. Given the number of closures we are scheduling, I'd say this saves us a micro or so per rpc.~~

Actually, my bad. It slipped my mind that assert does not emit any code if NDEBUG is defined, which means that there is nothing being saved really.
